articles.title: AUGUST 1989
articles.summary: This document outlines a schedule of astronomical events and club activities for August and September 1989, with a mention of a July star party. It details multiple star parties at various parks, general meetings, a total lunar eclipse, board meetings, and special programs including an astrophotography presentation and an introductory observational astronomy class. The schedule involves collaborations with other astronomy clubs and notes specific times for sunsets, moon phases, and twilight.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON & JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article details various activities and news for an astronomy club, including the presentation of the Dr. A. B. Gregory award to Tom Ahl and a successful Yosemite star party. It announces an upcoming 8th annual joint star party at Bonny Doon Airport on August 5th, an astrophotography class utilizing the Fremont Peak 30-inch telescope, and a September swap meet followed by an equipment night. Additionally, it provides information on NASA's Voyager II flyby of Neptune on August 25th, including broadcast details.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: ASTRO ADS provides a free classifieds service for individuals to sell non-commercial, astronomically related products and services. Submissions are due by the 15th of each month and run for approximately three months. The listings primarily feature a variety of used astronomical equipment, including telescopes, eyepieces, mounts, and astrophotography gear, from brands like Celestron, Meade, and Edmund.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article by Don Machholz discusses recent comet activity, highlighting the recovery of three returning comets and the discovery of a new one. It also introduces a section dedicated to comet observations and techniques, noting that experienced comet hunters often observe known comets. Specific mention is made of Periodic Comet Du Toit-Neujmin-Delporte (1989l), recently recovered by Jim Gibson at magnitude 18.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf (1989o)
articles.summary: The article primarily reports on the recovery of Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf (1989o) on July 4, noting its unexpected position and early appearance. It predicts the comet will brighten to magnitude 6 by early September and be observable for Northern Hemisphere skywatchers until late September. Brief updates are also provided for Sungrazing Comet 1989m (SMM 8) and Periodic Comet Gehrels 2 (1989n), including their observed magnitudes and closest approaches to the sun.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document presents an ephemeris for the Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf (1989o), covering the period from late July to early September. It provides daily astronomical data including Right Ascension and Declination for both 1950 and 2000 epochs, solar elongation, sky visibility, and apparent magnitude. This information is crucial for observers to locate and track the comet.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article discusses comet observing, highlighting its value for both scientific research and training potential comet hunters. It emphasizes the importance of becoming familiar with various comets, from bright to faint, before attempting to search for new ones. The author details the components of a proper comet observation, focusing on methods for estimating magnitude (brightness), coma size, appearance, and tail characteristics, while also stressing the need to record observational details like the method used and instrument specifications.

articles.title: FIELD OBSERVING SITE OF THE SANTA CRUZ ASTRONOMY CLUB
articles.summary: This document outlines the field observing site for the Santa Cruz Astronomy Club, located at the Bonny Doon Airport, provided through the courtesy of the airport's ownership. The primary content is a hand-drawn map offering detailed directions to the site from various surrounding areas, noting its distance from key local intersections and major highways.

articles.title: AUGUST STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: The article details methods for observing and documenting comets, including techniques for estimating coma size, determining the degree of condensation, and measuring tail length and position angle. It encourages amateur astronomers to contribute to comet observations, noting Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf. Additionally, the piece highlights August as a busy month for meteor showers, particularly emphasizing the annual Perseids as a major event.

articles.title: METEOR SHOWER SUMMARY
articles.summary: This article provides a summary of astronomical events and observing opportunities for August. It details several meteor showers, including the major Perseids, and outlines a partial solar eclipse (not visible in the U.S.), a total lunar eclipse, and two lunar graze/occultation events with specific times for PDT observers. Additionally, it presents a deep sky challenge to find the Egg Nebula (PK 80-6.1) for observers with large aperture telescopes.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on a wide range of astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. These friendly gatherings cater to diverse astronomical passions like astrophotography and telescope making, with meetings currently held on the first Saturday of each month.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. These events often include telescope observations in the parking lot or astrophotography slideshows indoors. The SJAA also uses these times for board meetings and monthly introductory astronomy workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon, at various locations ranging from local sites to Yosemite. Fremont Peak State Park is a particularly popular and frequently used location for serious deep sky observing and astrophotography, often drawing 50-100 telescopes during clear New Moon weekends. The article also provides details about the SJAA's monthly publication, EPHEMERIS, and lists its officers and board of directors.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options including standard, with a Sky & Telescope subscription, and junior memberships, along with their respective costs. It provides instructions on how to submit the application and payment (checks payable to SJAA) either at a meeting or by mail to the treasurer.
